awd_titl_txt: Conference: 2023 Frontiers of Engineering Symposia (US FOE, German-American FOE, Japan-America FOE, and EU-US FOE)
awd_abstract_narration:
The Frontiers of Engineering (FOE) Symposia, organized by the National Academy of Engineering, provide emerging engineering leaders from academia, industry, and government laboratories the opportunity to share research insights to facilitate an interdisciplinary transfer of knowledge and research methodologies. The nature of emerging technologies and how they fit together to create products and processes that drive economic growth makes it essential that engineers understand research developments, techniques and approaches beyond their own discipline. The FOE symposia serve as a catalyst to spur engineering innovation and foster collaborative networks of researchers within the United States and between engineers from the United States and partnering countries. The FOE program has the potential to benefit society both by supporting innovation and by increasing the visibility of engineering and the important ways in which engineers serve society.

This award will provide partial support for four Frontiers of Engineering (FOE) symposia, to be held in 2023. These symposia, organized by the National Academy of Engineering (NAE) in concert with international partner organizations, are for early career researchers. The meetings to be funded by this award in 2023 are: German-American FOE (March, 2023; Jülich, Germany); Japan-America FOE (July, 2023; Tokyo, Japan); US FOE (September, 2023; Boulder, CO); and EU-US FOE (October, 2023; Murray Hill, NJ). The 2023 German-American FOE will focus on: Sustainable Production/Circular Economy; The Hydrogen Economy; Neuromorphic Computing; and Supply Chain Resiliency. Topics for the 2023 Japan-America FOE symposium are: Computational Approaches to Address Infectious Diseases; Wearable Robotics; Materials by Design; Circular Economy. The US FOE meeting will address: Engineered Quantum Systems; Mining Resource Extraction/Critical Materials; Combating Disinformation; Complex Systems in the Context of Health Care. The EU-US meeting will cover: The Quantum Era Challenge; Future Challenges in Additive Manufacturing; Green Hydrogen; The Computational Era of Life Sciences. Approximately 100 outstanding young engineers for the U.S. symposium and 30 from each country for the bilateral symposia will participate. Each 2.5 day symposium will include plenary sessions, break-out and poster sessions, and opportunities for developing collaborative research partnerships. Sessions will consist of presentations on cutting-edge research, innovations, and emerging research opportunities in engineering fields relevant to the symposium. FOE symposium papers, abstracts, presentation videos, and slides will be made available on the FOE website (www.naefrontiers.org).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Office of Emerging Frontiers in Research and Innovation (EFRI)

por.por_cntn:
The Frontiers of Engineering (FOE) Symposia, organized by the National Academy of Engineering, provide highly accomplished early-career engineers from academia, industry, and government laboratories the opportunity to share their research and technical work, which facilitates interdisciplinary exchange across diverse engineering fields. The nature of emerging technologies and how they fit together to create products and processes that drive economic grown in an increasingly competitive environment have heightened the need for engineers to understand each other's disciplines. The  symposia are a catalyst for innovation that fosters collaborative networks of researchers within the United States and across national boundaries. This award provided partial support for the German-American FOE, March 22-25, in Juelich, Germany; Japan-America FOE, July 17-20, in Tokyo, Japan; US FOE, September 10-13, in Boulder, CO; and EU-US FOE, October 15-18, in Murray Hill, NJ. Presentations and discussion focused on topics such as neuromorphic computing, materials by design, engineered quantum systems, and challenges in additive manufacturing. The meetings included networking time, poster sessions, and breakout groups. Presentation abstracts, slides, and posters are available on the meeting websites at www.naefrontiers.org.

The following results and comments were obtained from surveys of meeting attendees:

GERMAN-AMERICAN FOE 

Meeting format: good or excellent: 98%
Quality of presentations: good or excellent: 98%
As a result of this symposium, do you expect to
-- conduct new/different research: Yes or maybe yes: 95%
-- work with new contacts/collaborators: Yes or maybe yes: 100%
-- pursue new funding opportunities: Yes or maybe yes: 92%

It was a unique experience to speak to a broad audience, but one made up of highly technical experts in each field so that they grasped concepts of a different field very quickly. I came away feeling like I am a better “engineering citizen” to be well informed in these diverse areas, not only their promise but also, importantly, the challenges.

Presentations were key in identifying collaboration partners, like supply chain resiliency and circular economy. The poster session, which had topics different from the presentations, triggered collaboration such as partnering for project Alvarium. Also, the socializing/connect time contributed to collaboration for topics that were neither the main topic nor the posters, like Edge data processing.

I already scheduled follow-up meetings with a professor from NCSU to discuss possible collaboration.

JAPAN-AMERICA FOE 

Meeting format: good or excellent: 96%
Quality of presentations: good or excellent: 95%
Gained something useful to work/research from presentations//discussion in other disciplines: yes or possibly: 94%//94%
Identified potential collaborative opportunities//applications of interdisciplinary approaches: yes or possibly: 94%//94%

I identified potential new research applications for the instrument I am developing.

I learned a lot about the work other people are doing and gained insight into industry vs. government vs. university jobs. I got some great teaching and group management advice from other professors.

This symposium fosters a great environment for meeting new people and learning about research outside my area of expertise. This is very useful for my role with a venture creation company where I identify technologies that show promise for commercialization.

US FOE 

Meeting format: good or excellent: 100%
Quality of presentations: good or excellent: 94%
Gained something useful to work/research from presentations//discussion in other disciplines: yes or possibly: 92%//95%
Identified potential collaborative opportunities//applications of interdisciplinary approaches: yes or possibly: 84%//88%
 
Even outside the technical topics, the sessions taught me a lot about how to curate great stories, and conversations with leaders taught me ways to motivate teams and work with stakeholders. There was so much to learn that wasn't technical!

The networking sessions were the most valuable aspect of the conference, and I made some genuine connections that I can bring back to my day-to-day work.

I use optimization for my research work, and it's the first application of quantum computing. I will definitely go behind quantum computing for my future research.

As a faculty member, I particularly enjoyed the presence of brilliant engineers from industry. I hope to work with them in the future.

EU-US FOE
Meeting format: good or excellent: 100%
Quality of presentations: good or excellent: 100%
Gained something useful to work/research from presentations//discussion in other disciplines: yes or possibly: 96%//96%
Identified potential collaborative opportunities//applications of interdisciplinary approaches: yes or possibly: 96%//92%

It was very stimulating to have researchers from a variety of disciplines at a similar career stage and learn about their research and institutions. Having a concentration of expertise in four disciplines gave me many insights compared to other events. 

The diversity of thought was amazing! I met 50 or so other people and almost everyone had a slightly different expertise. This allowed me to have really meaningful conversations about tools/techniques I can use in my area and at the same time help identify where I can help others. 

GRAINGER GRANTS

Two grants of $30,000 from The Grainger Foundation will be awarded to 2023 US FOE attendees who develop collaborative research projects. 


Last Modified: 03/01/2024
Modified by: Janet R Hunziker
